content.title: Climate Requirements for Leopard Geckos
content.content: Leopard geckos are desert-adapted reptiles from the arid regions of South Asia, where daytime temperatures reach 90-100×F and humidity stays low (20-40%) except in underground burrows. Unlike tropical species, they require hot basking zones, significant temperature drops at night, and low ambient humidity with access to localized high-humidity retreats. This guide covers how to create and maintain appropriate desert climate conditions.
Leopard geckos need a horizontal temperature gradient with a hot basking zone, warm hide, and cool retreat. This gradient allows them to thermoregulate by moving to different areas.

content.text: Target Temperature Ranges:

rows: Surface of stone directly under heat lamp
Inside hide box under basking area

content.content: Leopard geckos NEED high heat for proper digestion. Basking surface temps below 90×F result in poor digestion, regurgitation, weight loss, and lethargy. A 20-25×F gradient from basking (94-97×F) to cool end (70-77×F) is essential.
Overhead heating (heat lamps) is the primary and most natural heat source, mimicking sun-warmed rocks. Heat mats are supplemental only.

content.text: Heat Source Options:

rows: Primary heat×most efficient, intense surface heating
Gentle infrared heat, low fire risk, can run 24/7
Nighttime supplemental heat (no light), less efficient than halogen
Boosts warm hide temp if halogen insufficient, requires thermostat

content.content: NEVER use heat mats as the sole heat source×leopard geckos need overhead basking to mimic sun-warmed rocks. Heat mats should only supplement a hide that isn't reaching 90-92×F from the overhead lamp alone. Always use thermostats with heat mats to prevent burns.
Proper heat lamp positioning creates safe, effective basking zones while maintaining cool retreats for thermoregulation.

content.text: Heat Lamp Configuration:

rows: Houses bulb safely, directs heat downward
Flat slate, flagstone, or tile (dark colors best)
Absorbs and radiates heat, provides basking surface
Enclosed hide box directly under/adjacent to basking stone
Turns heat lamp off at night (natural temp drop)
Regulates heat mat to prevent overheating/burns

content.text: Adjusting Heat Output:

rows: Use dimmer to reduce power 10-20%, OR switch to 50-60w bulb
Raise dome 1-2" above screen, OR use dimmer at 80% power
No changes needed×monitor seasonally for room temp shifts
Remove dimmer to run at full power, OR lower dome closer to screen
Switch to 100-150w bulb, ensure basking stone is dark color (absorbs more heat)
Add thermostat-controlled heat mat under hide, covered with 1" substrate

content.content: Start with a 75w halogen and test for 48 hours. Dark-colored basking stones (slate, black tile) absorb more heat than light-colored stones. Measure surface temp with infrared gun, not air temperature.
Accurate temperature measurement is critical for leopard gecko health. Incorrect temps are the leading cause of digestive problems and lethargy.

content.text: Thermometer Types & Uses:

rows: PRIMARY TOOL×measure basking stone, hide floors, all substrate surfaces
Track basking stone or warm hide interior 24/7
NOT RECOMMENDED×inaccurate, doesn't measure critical surface temps
Place inside warm hide to maintain 90-92×F if using heat mat

content.text: Where to Measure Temperature:

rows: 2 hours after lights on (stabilized), measure center of stone
Midday when enclosure fully warmed up
Check gradient is smooth, not abrupt temp changes
Should drop to ambient room temp
1 hour after lights off×verify heat lamp turned off

content.content: ALWAYS measure surface temperatures, not air temperature. Leopard geckos thermoregulate by contact with warm surfaces (rocks, substrate), not by air temp. An infrared temp gun is essential×$15-20 investment that ensures proper heating.
Leopard geckos require LOW ambient humidity (30-40%) but MUST have access to a high-humidity retreat (humid hide at 70-80%) for shedding and hydration.

content.text: Target Humidity Levels:

rows: Daytime stable, may rise to 40-50% at night
Constant high humidity from damp substrate inside
Slightly higher than basking, still arid
Geckos retreat underground where humidity is higher

content.content: Ambient humidity consistently above 50% causes respiratory infections and skin problems. Humidity below 30% requires more frequent humid hide maintenance. A humid hide is NOT optional×it's mandatory equipment for preventing stuck shed and dehydration.
The humid hide is a microclimate that provides essential high humidity for shedding and hydration while keeping the rest of the enclosure arid.

content.text: Humid Hide Construction:

rows: Enclosed hide box with single entrance
Opaque, snug fit (gecko should fill space), plastic or ceramic
Damp sphagnum moss, paper towels, or coco fiber
Moist enough to clump when squeezed, not dripping
Away from heat lamp prevents rapid drying
Digital hygrometer probe placed inside hide
Mist substrate every 2-3 days, replace weekly
Should feel damp to touch, no standing water

content.text: Humid Hide Troubleshooting:

rows: Humid hide dries out in 24 hours
Placed too close to heat source, ambient humidity too low
Move to coolest area, use deeper layer of moss (2-3"), mist more frequently
Reduce misting frequency, ensure hide has ventilation hole, wring out moss
Hide too large/insecure, or humidity too high everywhere
Use smaller hide that gecko fills, verify ambient humidity is 30-40%
Increase misting to every 1-2 days, add more moss (1-2" layer)

content.content: A properly maintained humid hide should feel damp when you touch the substrate inside, with visible moisture but no pooling water. During shed cycles, geckos will spend extended time in the humid hide×this is normal and healthy behavior.
Ambient room temperature and humidity change with seasons, requiring adjustments to heating and humid hide maintenance.

content.text: Seasonal Climate Management:

rows: Reduce heat lamp wattage or use dimmer, increase ventilation, humid hide may need less misting
Difficulty maintaining basking temp, ambient humidity <20%
Increase wattage to 100-150w, add CHE for nighttime, humid hide needs daily misting
Monitor daily with temp gun, adjust dimmer as needed
Increase ventilation (larger screen top), ensure humid hide is localized high humidity only

content.text: Common Problems and Solutions:

rows: Gecko avoids basking, stays on cool end, pale coloration
Reduce wattage or use dimmer at 70-80%, raise dome 1-2" above screen
Gecko won't eat, lethargic, undigested food in feces
Increase wattage to 100-150w, lower dome closer to screen, use dark basking stone
Entire enclosure same temp, gecko stressed
Verify heat lamp on one end only, check cool end is 20-25×F cooler
Add thermostat-controlled heat mat under hide (covered with 1" substrate)
Humid hide not used or humidity too low inside
Verify humid hide 70-80% humidity, make hide smaller/more secure
Ambient humidity too high (>60%), poor ventilation
Increase ventilation, reduce ambient humidity to 30-40%, vet visit
Ambient humidity too low (<20%), or temps too hot
Check basking not >97×F, increase ambient humidity to 30-40%

content.content: Power outages or equipment failures require immediate intervention to prevent health consequences.

content.text: Emergency Interventions:

rows: Hand warmers in insulated container outside enclosure, blankets over 3 sides
48-72 hours (leopard geckos tolerate cold better than heat)
Move to coolest room, frozen water bottles outside enclosure
Emergency replacement bulb (any household incandescent as temp fix)
Relocate to air-conditioned room, remove all heat sources
Critical×ambient room temp >90×F can overheat gecko
Emergency soak: warm water bowl 15-20 min supervised
Repeat daily until shed completes, fix humid hide setup

content.content: If room temperature exceeds 85×F, remove heat lamps entirely. Leopard geckos can tolerate cooler temps temporarily but overheat quickly. Temperatures above 105×F for more than 30-60 minutes can be fatal.

content.text: Essential Climate Control Equipment:

rows: Supplemental warm hide heat if needed

content.content: Total equipment cost: $80-120 for complete climate control setup. Annual maintenance: $20-30 for bulb replacements. An infrared temp gun ($15-20) is the single most important tool×eliminates guesswork and ensures proper heating.
